chapter.pasuk: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job, and that man was sincere and upright, God-fearing and shunning evil.
Now seven sons and three daughters were born to him.

His livestock consisted of seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of cattle, five hundred she- donkeys, and very much production; and the man was greater than all the children of the East.
Now his sons would go and make a feast in each one's house on his day, and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

Now it would come about when the cycle of the feasting days would be over, that Job would send and summon them, and offer up burnt-offerings early in the morning burnt- offerings according to the number of all of them, for Job said, "Perhaps my sons have sinned and blasphemed God in their hearts." So would Job do all the days.
Now the day came about, and the angels of God came to stand beside the Lord, and the Adversary, too, came among them.
The Lord said to the Adversary, "Where are you coming from?" And the Adversary answered the Lord and said, "From going to and fro on the earth and from walking in it."
Now the Lord said to the Adversary, "Have you paid attention to My servant Job? For there is none like him on earth, a sincere and upright man, God-fearing and shunning evil."
And the Adversary answered the Lord and said, "Does Job fear God for nothing?
Haven't You made a hedge around him, his household, and all that he has on all sides? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his livestock has spread out in the land.
But now, stretch forth Your hand and touch all that he has, will he not blaspheme You to Your face?"
Now the Lord said to the Adversary, "Behold, all that he has is in your hands; only upon him do not stretch forth your hand." Now the Adversary left the presence of the Lord.
Now the day came about that his sons and daughters were dining and drinking wine at the home of their firstborn brother,
and a messenger came to Job and said, "The cattle were plowing, and the she-donkeys were grazing beside them,
and Sheba fell upon them and took them, and they slew the youths by the sword, and only I alone escaped to tell you."
This one was still talking, and another one came and said, "A tremendous fire fell from heaven and burned the flocks and the youths and consumed them; only I alone escaped to tell you."

This one was still talking, and another one came and said, "Chaldeans formed three bands, spread out on the camels and took them, and slew the youths with the sword, and only I alone escaped to tell you."
While this one was still talking, another one came and said, "Your sons and daughters were dining and drinking wine at the home of their firstborn brother,
when, behold, a great wind came from the other side of the desert, and struck the four corners of the house; it fell upon the youths, who died, and only I alone escaped to tell you."
Then Job stood up, and rent his robe and tore his hair; then he fell to the ground and prostrated himself.
And he said, "From my mother's womb, I emerged naked, and I will return there naked. The Lord gave and the Lord took; may the name of the Lord be blessed."
Despite all this, Job did not sin, neither did he ascribe unseemliness to God.
Now the day came about that the angels of God came to stand beside the Lord, and the Adversary too came among them to stand beside the Lord.
Now the Lord said to the Adversary, "Where are you coming from?" And the Adversary replied to the Lord and said, "From going to and fro on the earth and from walking in it."

And the Lord said to the Adversary, "Have you paid attention to My servant Job? For there is none like him in the earth, a sincere and upright man, God-fearing and shunning evil, and he still maintains his sincerity. Yet you enticed Me against him."
Now the Adversary replied to the Lord and said, "Skin for skin, and whatever a person has he will give for his life.
But, stretch forth Your hand now and touch his bones and his flesh, will he not blaspheme You to Your face?"
And the Lord said to the Adversary, "Here he is in your hands, but preserve his life."
Now the Adversary departed from the presence of the Lord, and he smote Job with severe boils from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
Then he took himself a potsherd to scratch himself with, and he sat down in the midst of the ashes.
Then his wife said to him, "Do you still maintain your sincerity? Blaspheme God and die!"
And he said to her, "You talk as one of the disgraceful women talks. Shall we also accept the good from God, and not accept the evil?" Despite all this, Job did not sin with his lips.

Now Job's three friends heard about all this evil that befell him, and they came, each one from his place; Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, and they met together to come to bemoan him and console him.
Now they lifted their eyes [and looked] from afar but they did not recognize him; so they raised their voices and wept, and each one rent his robe, and they threw earth on their heads towards heaven.
Now they sat down with him on the ground for seven days and seven nights, but no one said a word to him because they perceived that the pain was very severe.
Afterwards, Job opened his mouth and cursed his day.
Now Job raised his voice and said,
"Would the day in which I was to be born be lost, and the night when one said, 'A man has impregnated.'
May that day be dark; let God not seek it from above, and let no light shine upon it.
May darkness and the shadow of death defile it; let pitch darkness dwell upon it; let them frighten it like demons of the day.
That night-may pitch darkness take it; it shall not rejoice among the days of the year; in the number of months it shall not come.
Behold that night shall be lonely; no joyful singing shall come therein.
May those who curse the day, curse it-those destined to be childless in their union.
May the stars of its evening be darkened; it shall hope for light but have none, neither shall it see the rays of dawn.
For He did not shut the doors of my womb, neither did He hide trouble from my eyes.
Why did I not die from the womb? [Why did I not] emerge from the belly and perish?
Why did knees receive me and why [were there] breasts that I should suck?
For now, I would be lying tranquilly; I would sleep, then it would be restful for me.
With kings and counselors of the earth, who build ruins for themselves,
Or with princes who have gold, who fill their houses with silver.
Or [why] was I not like a hidden stillborn child, like infants who did not see the light?
There the wicked cease from anger, and there the weary rest.
Together prisoners are tranquil; they hear not the voice of the taskmaster.
Small and great are there, and a slave is free from his master.
Why does He give the toiler light and life to those of bitter spirit?
Who await death and it is not here, and they spy after it more than after hidden treasures.
Those who are happy over joyous occurrences, rejoice when they find a grave
for a man whose way is hidden, and God hedged him in.
For before my meal comes my sigh, and my moans pour like water.
For the thing I feared has befallen me, and what I dreaded is coming upon me.
I was not at ease, neither was I quiet, and I did not rest, yet trouble came.
Now Eliphaz the Temanite raised his voice and said,
"Because He tested you with [one] thing, should you weary? Who can withhold words?
Behold, you have chastised many, and you have strengthened weak hands.
Your words would pick up the stumbler, and you would strengthen buckling knees.
Now when it comes to you, you weary; it touches you and you are frightened.
Surely, your fear was your foolishness, your hope and the sincerity of your ways.
Remember now, who was innocent that perished, and where were the upright destroyed?
As I have seen, those who plow violence and sow mischief will reap it.
From the breath of God they will perish, and from the wind of His nostrils they will be destroyed.
The roar of an old lion, the voice of a young lion, and the teeth of lion cubs were misled.
A lion perishes without prey, and the young of the lion will scatter.
Now a word was conveyed secretly to me, and my ear grasped a bit of it.
In the thoughts of the visions of night, when slumber falls on people,
terror and quaking befell me, and He frightened most of my bones.
And a spirit passed by my face; it made the hair of my flesh stand on end.
It was standing, but I did not recognize its appearance, this image before my eyes; I heard a faint voice.
Can a mortal be more righteous than God, or can a man be purer than his Maker?
Behold, He does not trust His servants and He casts reproach upon His angels.
Surely those who dwell in mud houses, whose foundation is in dust; they crush them before the worms.
From morning to evening they are crushed without giving [a thought]; they perish to eternity.
Their haughtiness, which is absorbed within them-does it not leave [them]? They die, and not with wisdom.
Now call; will anyone answer you? To which of the holy ones will you turn?
For anger will kill a fool, and wrath will kill a naive person.
I have seen a fool taking root, and suddenly I cursed his dwelling.
May his sons distance themselves from salvation, and may they be crushed in the gate without a rescuer.
The hungry shall eat his harvest, and he will take it for the one saved from his weapons, and one of the thirsty shall swallow their riches.
For not from the dust does ruin emerge, and not from the soil does trouble spring,
because man is born for trouble, but flying creatures fly upward.
But I would seek of God, and to God I would commit my cause,
Who does things great and unsearchable, wonders without number,
Who gives rain upon the face of the land and sends water upon the face of outside places,
to place the humble on high, and those blackened are exalted by salvation.
He frustrates the plans of the crafty, so that their hands do not carry out their plans.
He takes the wise in their own craftiness, and the counsel of the crooked is hasty.
By day, they meet darkness, and they grope at noon as at night.
And He saved [them] from the sword of their mouth, and the needy from the hand of the mighty.
So it was hope for the poor, and libel shut its mouth.
Behold, fortunate is the man whom God reproves; so do not despise the chastening of the Almighty.
For He brings pain and binds it; He wounds, and His hands heal.
In six troubles He will save you, and in the seventh no harm will touch you.
In famine, He redeemed you from death, and in war, from the power of the sword.
You shall be hidden from the scourging tongue, and you shall not fear plunder when it comes.
You shall mock plunder and hoarding, and you shall not fear the beasts of the land.
But you have a treaty with the stones of the field, and the beasts of the field made peace with you.
Then you shall know that there is peace in your tent, and you shall visit your habitation and miss nothing.
And you shall know that your seed shall be many, and your offspring [as numerous] as the grass of the earth.
You shall come to the grave at a ripe old age, as the grain stack is taken away in its time.
Behold this; we have inquired into it, so it is. Listen to it, and you-know for yourself. "
Now Job replied and said,
"If only my anger and my calamity were weighed, placed together on a scale,
for now, it would be heavier than the sand of the seas; therefore, my words stammer.
For the Almighty's arrows are with me, whose venom my spirit drinks; the terrors of God wage war with me.
Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass or does an ox low over its fodder?
Can bland food be eaten without salt, or is there a taste in the saliva of strong-tasting food?
What my body refused to touch-they are as cloths for my food.
Would that my request were granted, and God would give what I hope for.
And may God desire and crush me, enlarge His hand and finish me off.
Then should I yet have comfort, and I will beg, shuddering, that he have no pity, for I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
What is my strength that I should wait and what is my end that I should restrain my desire?
Is my strength the strength of stones or is my flesh copper?
Have I no help, or is counsel lost to me?
By one who withholds kindness from his friend and who abandons the fear of the Almighty?
My brethren have betrayed [me] like a stream; like the source of streams they pass,
which wrinkle from the ice-upon them snow is hidden.
At the time they become warm, they retreat; when it heats up, they jump from their place.
The paths of their way are held [by them]; they go up in waste and are lost.
They look at the paths of Tema; they make a line for the roads of Sheba.
They are ashamed because they had hoped; they came to it and were disgraced.
For now you are like it; you fear ruin; yea you fear.
Did I say, "Give me," or "Offer a bribe for me from your wealth"?
And "Rescue me from an enemy," and "Ransom me from the hands of tyrants"?
Instruct me and I will be silent, and allow me to understand where I have erred.
How clear are words of uprightness, but what does your proof prove?
Do you think to clarify words? They are like wind, words of futility.
You cast wrath upon an orphan, and you dig [a pit] for your friend.
But now, agree and turn to me and [see] whether I lie to your face.
Return now; there will be no injustice, and return again [to see that] my cause is righteous.
Is there injustice in my tongue, or will my palate not understand wickedness?
Is not man on earth for a limited time, and are his days [not] like the days of a hireling?
As a slave, who longs for the shadow, and as a hireling who hopes for his wages,
so was I made to possess months of futility, and they appointed wearisome nights for me.
If I would lie down, I would say, 'When shall I arise, and [when will] the evening depart?' And I was sated with restlessness until twilight.
My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of earth; my skin wrinkled and melted.
My days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle and are spent without hope.
Remember that my life is wind; my eye will not return to see good.
The eye of him who sees me shall see me no more; set Your eyes upon me and I will be here no longer.
Just as a cloud is consumed and goes away, so will one who descends to the grave not ascend.
He shall never again return to his house, neither shall his place recognize him again.
Neither will I restrain my mouth; I will speak with the anguish of my spirit, I will complain with the bitterness of my soul.
Am I a sea or a sea monster, that You place a watch over me?
Should I say that my bed shall comfort me, that my couch shall bear my speech
You terrify me with dreams, and You frighten me with visions,
so that my soul chooses strangling; death rather than these my bones.
I despised [my life]; I will not live forever; desist from me for my life is futility.
What is man that You should give him importance, or that You should pay attention to him?
That you should visit him every morning and try him every moment.
How long will You not desist from me, will You not let me go until I swallow my spit?
I have sinned; what do I do to You? O watcher of man, why have You made me as a mark for You, so that I have become a burden to myself?
Now why do You not forgive my transgression and remove my iniquity, for now I will lie on the dust; and You shall seek me but I am not here.
Now Bildad the Shuhite replied and said:
"How long will you speak such things, seeing that the words of your mouth are [like] a mighty wind?
Does God pervert judgment, or does the Almighty pervert justice?
If your children sinned against Him, He sent them away in the hands of their transgression.
If you seek God and supplicate the Almighty,
if you are pure and upright, He shall arouse [your merit] over you, and will complete your righteous home.
And your beginning shall be small, but your end shall increase exceedingly.
For inquire now about the past generation and apply yourself to what their fathers have searched out,
For we are of yesterday and know nothing, because our days on earth are like a shadow.
Will they not instruct you and tell you, and utter words out of their heart?
Can papyrus shoot up without a marsh? Can the reed-grass grow without water?
When it is still in its greenness, it will not be plucked, but before any other grass, it will dry up.
So are the ways of all those who forget God, and the hope of the flatterer shall be lost,
whose confidence shall be cut off, and whose trust is a spider's web.
He leans on his house but it does not stand; he grasps it but it does not endure.
It is fresh before the sun, and on its garden its tender branch emerges.
Beside the fountain, its roots are entwined; he sees a stone house.
If one destroys him from his place, then it shall deny him, [saying] 'I have not seen you.'
Behold this is the joy of his way, and from the earth, others will spring forth.
Behold God will not reject the innocent, nor will he uphold evildoers.
Until He fills your mouth with laughter and your lips with shouting.
Your enemies will be clothed with shame, and the tent of the wicked shall be no more."
Then Job replied and said,
"Indeed, I know that it is so, but why should a man be righteous with God?
If he would wish to contend with Him He would not answer him one out of a thousand.
He is wise in heart and mighty in strength; who hardened [his heart] against Him and remained whole?
He Who moved mountains but they knew not that He had overturned them in His wrath;
He Who causes the earth to quake from its place, and its pillars shudder;
He Who spoke to the sun and it did not shine, and He sealed up the stars;
He Who alone stretched out the heavens and treads on the high places of the sea;
He Who made the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the chambers of the south;
He Who performs great deeds without limit, and wonders until they have no number
Behold, He goes by me but I do not see [Him]; and He passes but I do not perceive Him.
Behold, He strikes suddenly, and who can hold Him back; who will say to Him, 'What are You doing?'
God will not hold back His wrath; all the helpers of Rahab stoop under Him.
Surely, that I should answer Him; that I should choose my words with Him.
For if I am right, I will not reply; will I supplicate my Judge?
If I call and He answers me, I will not believe that He would hearken to my voice
He Who would crush me with a tempest and multiply my wounds for nought;
He Who would not let me catch my breath, for he would sate me with bitterness.
If it is a trial of strength- behold He is mighty; and if of judgment-who will summon me?
If I am innocent, my mouth will condemn me; if blameless, it will make me crooked.
I am blameless, but I do not know how to find rest; I despise my life.
It is all one; therefore I said, 'He destroys both the innocent and the wicked.'
If the scourge kills suddenly, he will mock at the calamity of the innocent.
The earth has been given into the hands of a wicked one; he covers the faces of its judges. If not, then who is he?
My days are swifter than a runner; they fled, they saw no good.
They passed with the ships of Ebeh, like an eagle that swoops upon food.
If I say, 'Let me forget my complaint, I will abandon my anger and restrain myself.'
I will gather in all my sadness, I know that You will not declare me innocent.
If I am wicked, why should I toil in vain?
I washed myself with snow water and cleansed my hands with purity.
Then You will plunge me in the ditch, and my garments shall abhor me.
For He is not man like me, that I should answer Him, 'Let us come together in debate.'
There is no arbiter between us, who will place his hand on both of us.
Let Him take His rod off me, and let His terror not frighten me.
I will speak and I will not fear Him, for I am not so with myself.
My soul quarrels with my life; I will leave my speech with me; I will speak with the bitterness of my life.
I will say to God, 'do not condemn me; let me know why You quarrel with me.
Is it good to You that You should oppress, that You should reject the toil of Your hands, and shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
Do You have eyes of flesh, or do You see as a man sees?
Are Your days like the days of a mortal, or are Your years like the days of a man,
that You should search for my iniquity and seek my sin?
It is in Your knowledge that I will not be condemned, but no one can save [me] from Your hand.
Your hands shaped me and made me; [Your hosts are] together round about, and You destroy me.
Remember now that You made me like clay, and You will return me to dust.
Did You not pour me like milk and curdle me like cheese?
Clothe me with skin and flesh and cover me with bones and sinews?
You have granted me life and kindness, and Your providence watched my spirit.
But You hid these in Your heart; I knew that it was with You.
If I sinned, You watched me, and would not cleanse me of my iniquity,
If I dealt wickedly, woe is to me; and if I am righteous I will not raise my head, sated with disgrace and seeing my affliction.
And it is so great that You hunt me like a lion, and You repeatedly pronounce a verdict upon me.
You renew Your witnesses against me, and You increase Your anger with me; shifts with set times are with me.
Now why did You take me out of the womb? Would that I had died and no eye had seen me.
Then I would have been as though I had not existed; would that I was brought from the womb to the grave.
Are not my days few? So desist and withdraw from me, and I will strengthen myself a little,
before I go and do not return, to a land of darkness and the shadow of death,
a land of darkness like darkness itself; the shadow of death without orders, and where the light is as darkness.' "
Now Zophar the Naamathite replied and said,
"Should not a multitude of words be answered, or should a talkative person be accounted right?
Your fabrications may silence men, and you mock with no one to embarrass you.
You said, 'My doctrine is pure, and I was clean in your eyes.'
But, would that God would speak and open His lips with you,
and tell you mysteries of wisdom for the wisdom is double, and know that God lends you of your iniquity.
Can you find out the mystery of God; can you find out the limit of the Almighty?
[In] the heights of heaven, what will you do? Deeper than the grave, what do you know?
Longer than the earth is its measure, and wider than the sea.
If He passes and confines and assembles, who can hinder Him?
For He knows deceitful people; when He sees iniquity, He does not consider it.
But an empty man will gain understanding, and [from] a wild donkey a man will be born.
If you prepare your heart and spread out your hands to Him,
if there is iniquity in your hand, distance it, and do not allow injustice to dwell in your tents.
For then you will lift your face without a blemish, and you shall be strong and shall not fear,
for you shall forget trouble; like water that has passed shall you remember.
And your luck shall rise more than midday; your darkness shall be like the morning.
And you shall trust for there is hope, and you shall dig [around yourself] and lie in safety.
And you shall lie down and no one will frighten you, and great men will supplicate you.
And the eyes of the wicked shall fail, and they shall have no way to flee, and their hope shall result in intense grief."
Now Job replied and said,
"Indeed you are a people, and wisdom shall perish with you.
[But] I too have intelligence like you; I am not inferior to you, and with whom are there none comparable to these?
I am as one who is a laughingstock to his friend, one who calls to God and He answers him that the completely righteous will have laughter.
A brand of contempt is for the thought of the tranquil, is prepared for those whose foot has slipped.
The tents of robbers prosper, and those who provoke God are secure, to whomever God brought it with His hand.
But now inquire of the beasts and they will instruct you, and of the fowl of the heavens and they will tell you.
Or speak to the earth and it will instruct you, and the fishes of the sea will tell you.
Who does not know of all these? For the hand of the Lord has done this,
in Whose hand is the soul of all living and the spirit of all human flesh.
Does not the ear discern words and the palate taste its food?
In elders there is wisdom and in longevity there is understanding.
With Him is wisdom and might; He has counsel and understanding.
Behold, He breaks down and it cannot be rebuilt; He shuts up a man and there can be no opening.
Behold He withholds the water and it dries up; He sends it away and it overturns the earth.
With Him is might and counsel; His are the misled and the misleader.
He leads counselors away with madness and He makes judges into fools.
He loosens the bond of kings and He binds a girdle to their loins.
He leads princes away with madness and He overthrows the mighty.
He removes the speech from trusty men, and takes away the sense of the elders.
He pours contempt upon princes and loosens the belt of the strong.
He uncovers deep things out of darkness and brings to light the shadow of death.
He makes nations great and destroys them; He spreads out the nations and leads them.
He takes away the intelligence of the heads of the people of the land, and He causes them to wander in a wasteland [that is] not a road.
They grope in the darkness without light, and he causes them to wander like a drunkard.
Behold my eye has seen everything; my ear has heard and understood it.
I know as much as you; I too am not inferior to you.
But I would speak to the Almighty, and I wish to reason with God.
But you combine lies; all of you are quacks.
Would that you kept silent, and it would be accounted as wisdom for you.
Hearken now to my reasoning, and listen to the contentions of my lips.
Will you speak unjustly for God, and will you speak deceitfully for Him?
Will you show Him favor? Will you contend for God?
Will it be good when He searches you out? Will you mock Him as one mocks a mortal?
He will surely reprove you- will you secretly show favor?
Will not His majesty terrify you? Will [not] His fear fall upon you?
Your memorials are compared to ashes; your eminences are like eminences of clay.
Keep your peace and leave me alone, so that I will speak, and let come upon me what may.
For what reason shall I bring my flesh up into my teeth, and take my life into my hand?
Behold, let Him kill me, I will hope for Him; but I will prove my ways to His face.
He is also my salvation, because a hypocrite cannot come before Him.
Hearken to my word, and to my speech in your ears.
Behold now I have set up judgment; I know that I will be accounted innocent.
Who will contend with me, for now I will be silent and perish.
But do not do two things to me; then I will not hide from before You.
Distance Your compulsion from upon me, and let Your fear not terrify me.
But call, and I will answer, or I will speak and You answer me.
How many iniquities and sins do I have? Let me know my transgression and my sin.
Why do You hide Your face and regard me as Your enemy?
Will You frighten a rattling leaf? Will You pursue dry stubble?
That You should write disobediences against me and cause me to inherit the iniquities of my youth?
And that You should put my feet in the stocks and guard all my ways; You engrave my footsteps.
And it is like rot that decays like a moth-eaten garment.
Man, born of woman, short of days and full of fear.
As a blossom, he emerges and is cut off; he flees like a shadow and does not stand.
Do You open Your eyes also on this one and bring me into judgment with You?
Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean one? Not one.
If his days are limited, and the number of his months is with You, You set his bounds and he cannot cross.
Turn away from him that he may rest, until, like a hireling, he desires his day.
For a tree has hope; if it is cut it will again renew itself, and its bough will not cease.
If its root ages in the earth, and in the dust its trunk dies,
from the smell of water it will blossom, and it will produce a branch like a sapling.
But a man will die and he is weakened; man perishes and where is he?
As the waters fail from the sea, and the river is drained dry.
So does a man lie down and not rise; until the heavens are no more, they will not awaken, nor will they be aroused from their sleep.
Would that You hide me in the grave, that You would keep me secret, until Your wrath has subsided; give me a set time and remember me.
If a man dies, will he live? All the days of my lifespan, I will hope, until the coming of my passing.
Call and I will answer You; You desire the work of Your hands.
But now, You count my steps; You do not wait for my sin.
My transgression is sealed up in a bundle, and You have attached Yourself to my iniquity.
And surely the falling mountain gives forth produce and the rock that moves from its place.
Stones [which] the water eroded; it washes away into dust its aftergrowth, but the hope of man You have destroyed.
You overpower him to eternity and he goes away, [You] change his countenance and You send him away.
His sons become wealthy but he does not know it; and they become poor but he does not understand.
But his flesh causes him pain, and his soul mourns for him."
Now Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
"Shall a wise man raise his voice with opinions of wind, and does he fill his belly with the east wind?
To debate over a matter from which he derives no benefit and words in which there is no avail?
Surely you will do away with fear and increase speech before God.
For your iniquity teaches your mouth, but you should have chosen the tongue of the crafty.
Let your own mouth condemn you and not I, and let your own lips testify against you.
Were you born before Adam? Were you created before the hills?
Did you listen to the counsel of God and increase wisdom to yourself?
What do you know that we do not know? [What do] you understand that is not with us?
Both old and ancient are among us, who have more days than your father.
Are God's consolations little for you, and the thing that He gave you gently?
What does your heart teach you and what do your eyes hint?
That you should return your wind to God and let words come out of your mouth.
What is man that he should be innocent, and that one born of woman should be just?
Lo! He does not believe in His holy ones, and the heavens are not pure in His eyes.
Surely [not] one who is abominable and impure, a man who drinks injustice like water.
I will tell you, listen to me; and this I saw and I will tell.
That the wise men tell and do not hide from their fathers.
To them alone the land was given, and no stranger passed in their midst.
All the days of a wicked man, he mourns, even the number of years that are laid up for the oppressor.
The voice of terrors is in his ears; in peace a robber will come upon him.
He will not believe that he shall return from darkness, and he is destined to the sword.
He wanders for bread, where is it? He knows that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.
Distress and anguish frighten him; it overpowers him like a king destined for the inferno,
for he stretched his hand to God and showed his strength against the Almighty.
He runs toward Him with his neck upright, with the thickness of the body of his shields.
For he has covered his face with his fat, and he has made collops of fat on his loins.
And he dwelt in ruined cities, in houses that could not be inhabited, that were destined to become heaps.
He will not become wealthy, and his possessions will not remain; neither will the gratification of their desire bend to the earth.
He will not turn away from darkness; a flame will dry out his young branches, and he will turn away by the breath of His mouth.
He who was misled by futility will not believe that his recompense shall be futility.
Before his time it will be completed, and his branches will not be green.
He will cast off his unripe grapes like a vine, and he will throw off his blossom like an olive tree.
Because the company of a hypocrite is lonely, and a fire consumes the tents of bribery.
They conceive trouble and bear iniquity, and their belly prepares deceit."
Now Job replied and said,
"I have heard such [things] many [times]; you are all troublesome consolers.
Is there an end to words of wind? Or what will bring clarity to you that you should answer?
I, too, could speak like you; if your soul were instead of my soul, I would join words together against you and shake my head at you.
I would encourage you with my mouth, and the movement of my lips would cease.
Should I speak, my pain will not cease, and should I stop, what will leave me?
but now, it has wearied me; you have silenced all my company.
You have shrivelled me up; it has become a witness. My leanness has risen against me; it testifies before me.
His wrath has torn me; yea, He hates me, He has gnashed His teeth at me. My Adversary sharpens his eyes upon me.
They open their mouth at me, with disdain they strike my cheeks; united they assemble against me.
God delivers me to a fool and heals me through the hands of the wicked.
I was tranquil, but he crumbled me to pieces; He held me by my nape and shattered me, and stood me up as a target for him.
His archers surround me; he splits my kidneys and does not have compassion. He spills out my gall upon the ground.
He breached me [with] breach upon breach; he runs toward me like a mighty warrior.
I sewed sackcloth on my scabs and sullied my radiance in the dust.
My face became shrivelled from crying, and upon my eyelids is the shadow of death.
But not because of any violence in my hands, and my prayer is pure.
O earth! do not cover my blood, and let there be no place for my cry.
Even now, behold my Witness is in heaven and He Who testifies for me is on high.
My intercessors, my friends, to God my eye pours out tears.
Would that a man could reason with God as a man with his fellow.
For numbered years will come, and I will go on a way from which I will not return.
My spirit has been destroyed, my days flicker; graves are ready for me,
even if there were no mockers with me, and in their provocation my eye [did not] abide.
Pay heed now, give me surety with You, for who is it who will shake hands with me?
For You have hidden their hearts from understanding; therefore, You will not be exalted.
He who speaks to his friends with flattery-his children's eyes will fail.
And it set me up as a byword for peoples, and I will be [like] a drum before them.
And my eye is dimmed from anger, and my limbs are all like a shadow.
The upright will be appalled by this, and an innocent one will be aroused against a hypocrite.
Yet the righteous holds on his way, and the one whose hands are clean grows stronger and stronger.
But all of them, [I say] you shall return and come now, and I will not find any wise man among you.
My days have passed, yea my purposes; the thoughts of my heart have been broken off.
They turn night into day; the light is short because of the darkness.
Since I hope for the grave as my house, in the darkness I have spread out my couch.
To the pit I have called, 'You are my father'; 'My mother,' and 'My sister,' to the worms.
Where then is my hope? And as for my hope, who shall see it?
The limbs of the grave shall descend, even together they rest on the dust."
Now Bildad the Shuhite answered and said,
"How long? Make an end to the words. Consider, and afterwards we will speak.
Why are we considered like an animal? and reputed dull in your sight?
One who destroys his soul in his anger! Shall the earth be abandoned for your sake, and shall the Rock be removed from His place?
Yea, the light of the wicked shall be put out and the spark of his fire shall not light.
The light shall become dark in his tent, and his candle that is over him shall go out.
The steps of his strength shall be straitened, and his counsel shall cast him down.
For he shall be sent into a net with his feet, and he shall walk on the toils.
A trap shall seize him by the heel; He shall strengthen the thirsty ones over him.
A noose is hidden for him in the ground, and a trap for him on the path.
All around, terrors frighten him, and beat him off his feet.
His son shall be hungry, and a misfortune shall be ready for his wife.
He shall eat the branches of his body; the prince of death shall devour his branches.
He shall be torn away from his wife who trusted him, and she will send him to the king of terrors.
She shall dwell in his tent, not being his; brimstone shall be scattered upon his dwelling.
From beneath, his roots shall dry up, and from above, his branch shall be cut off.
His remembrance shall be lost from the earth, and he has no name in the street.
They shall drive him from light into darkness and chase him from the world.
He shall have neither son nor grandson in his people, and there shall be no survivor in his dwelling places.
Concerning his day-the later people shall be astonished, and the earlier ones shall be seized by quaking.
These are [fit] only [for] the dwellings of the unrighteous, and this [for] the place of him who did not know God."
Now Job answered and said,
"How long will you grieve my soul and crush me with words?
Already ten times you humiliate me; you are not ashamed to alienate yourselves from me.
And even if I have indeed erred, let my error stay with me.
If indeed, you are added to my [troubles], and prove against me my reproach.
Know then that God has perverted my cause, and He has encompassed me with His net.
Behold, I cry out [concerning] violence but I am not answered; I cry aloud but there is no justice.
He has fenced in my way so that I cannot pass, and He places darkness on my paths.
He has stripped me of my honor, and removed the crown from my head.
He has broken me down all around and I have gone away; He has uprooted my hope like a tree.
He has kindled His wrath against me, and He has regarded me as [one of] His enemies.
Together His troops advance; they build their road against me, and camp around my tent.
He has distanced my brothers from me, and my friends became strange to me.
My relatives are gone, and my familiar friends have forgotten me.
Those who live in my house and my maidservants consider me a stranger; in their sight I am a foreigner.
I call my servant and he does not respond; with my mouth I appeal to him.
My breath is strange to my wife, and I appeal to the children of my body.
Even children despised me; I get up and they talk about me.
All my intimate friends abhor me; and those whom I loved turned against me.
My bones cleaved to my skin and to my flesh, and I escaped by the skin of my teeth.
Have pity on me, have pity on me, you, my friends, for God's hand has touched me.
Why do you persecute me like God, and why are you not sated with my flesh?
Would then that my words be written; would that they were inscribed in a book!
With an iron pen and lead, forever on the rock they should be hewn.
But I know that my Redeemer lives, and the last on earth, He will endure.
And after my skin, they have cut into this, and from my flesh I see judgment.
That I see for myself, and my eyes have seen and not a stranger; my kidneys are consumed within me.
Shall you say, 'Why should we persecute him?' And what is the root of the matter found in me?
Fear the sword, for the wrath of iniquities is the sword, in order that you know the plunder."
Now Zophar the Naamathite answered and said,
"Therefore my thoughts will cause me to answer me, and because of my silence that is within me,
the chastisement of my disgrace I hear, and a spirit of my understanding will answer me.
Do you know this from time immemorial, since man was placed on the earth,
that the triumph of the wicked is short, and the joy of the flatterers is but a moment?
If his height ascends to the heavens and his head reaches the clouds,
like his dung, he shall perish forever; those who see him will say, 'Where is he?'
Like a dream, he will fly away and they will not find him; and he will wander away like a vision of the night.
The eye that glimpsed him will do so no more, and his place will see him no longer.
His sons will placate the poor, and his hands will return his plunder.
His bones are full of his youth, and it will lie on the dust with him.
Though evil be sweet in his mouth, though he hide it under his tongue;
Though he spare it and will not let it go, but keep it on the middle of his palate;
His food will turn into the venom of cobras within him.
He swallowed up wealth and vomited it out, and from his belly God will cast it.
He will suck the venom of cobras; the tongue of the carpet viper will kill him.
He will not see the rivulets, the flowing rivers of honey and cream.
He will return that which he labored for and he will not swallow it; when his gain becomes vast wealth, he will not rejoice.
When he oppressed, he abandoned the poor; he stole a house, which he did not build.
For he did not know any rest in his stomach; with his beauty he will not save anything.
Nothing remains of his food; therefore his goods shall not prosper.
When his desire has been filled sufficiently, he will be in straits; the hand of every laborer will come upon him.
It shall come to pass that to fill his belly, He shall send upon him His burning wrath and rain upon them with His battle.
He shall flee from iron weapons; a copper bow shall pierce him.
One drew it and it emerged from its sheath and its glittering blade shall come forth from its bitterness, [bringing] terrors upon him.
All darkness is hidden for what awaits him; fire that was not blown shall consume him; harm shall befall the survivor in his tent.
The heavens shall reveal his iniquity and the earth shall rise up against him.
The produce of his house shall go into exile; [his goods] shall flow away on the day of His wrath.
This is the lot of a wicked man, from God; and the inheritance appointed him by God."
Now Job answered and said,
"Listen closely to my word, and this shall be your consolations.
Bear with me and I will speak, and after my speech you may mock.
Am I speaking to man? Why then should I not be short of breath?
Turn to me and be silent, and place your hand upon your mouth.
Now when I remember, I become frightened, and my flesh is seized with shuddering.
Why do the wicked live on, grow strong and powerfully rich?
Their children are well established in their sight with them, and their children's children are before their eyes.
Their houses have peace from fear, and God's rod is not upon them.
His bull impregnates and does not fail; his cow bears young and does not abort.
They send forth their infants like sheep, and their children dance.
They raise [their voice] with the tambourine and the harp, and they rejoice to the sound of the flute.
They end their days in prosperity, and in a moment they descend to the grave.
They said to God, 'Turn away from us; we do not wish to know Your ways.
What is the Almighty that we should serve Him, and what will it avail us that we should pray to Him?'
Behold, is not their prosperity in their hand? The counsel of the wicked has distanced itself from me.
How long? May the lamp of the wicked be snuffed out, and may their ruin befall them; may He distribute lots in His anger.
they shall be like straw before the wind and like chaff that the tempest has stolen.
Should God lay away his pain for his sons? Let Him requite him so that he should know.
Let his eyes see his ruin, and let him drink of God's wrath.
For what does He care about his house after him since the number of his months has been cut off?
Can anyone teach knowledge for God? But He judges high-handedly.
This one dies in his full strength, completely tranquil and peaceful.
His pails are full of milk, and the marrow of his bones is moist.
And this one dies with a bitter spirit, having partaken of no good.
Together on the earth they lie, and the worms cover them.
Lo, I know your thoughts and the devices that you wrongfully think against me.
For you will say, 'Where is the house of the prince, and where is the tent [and] the dwellings of the wicked?'
Have you not asked the wayfarers? Then do not make their signs strange [to yourselves].
That the wicked man is reserved for the day of calamity; they are brought for the day of wrath.
Who will tell His way to His face? He did, and who will requite Him?
But he will be borne to the grave and he will hasten to be beside the stacks of grain.
The clods of the valley will be sweet to him, and all men draw after him as there were innumerable ones before him.
Now how do you comfort me with futility, and [only] betrayal remains of your replies."
Now Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
"Does a man benefit God when he teaches them wisdom?
Does the Almighty care if you are righteous, or is there any gain if you perfect your ways?
Will He reason with you because He fears you? Will He come with you to judgment?
Is not your evil great, and are not your iniquities without end?
For you take a pledge from your brothers for nought, and you strip them naked of their clothes.
You gave the faint no water to drink, and you withheld bread from the hungry.
Does a strong man own the earth, and does a respected one remain therein?
You sent widows away empty-handed, and the arms of the orphans are crushed.
Therefore, around you are traps, and sudden fear terrifies you.
Or darkness so that you do not see; or an abundance of water covers you.
Is not God in the height of heaven, and [does He not] behold the topmost of the stars, which are lofty?
And you say, 'What does God know? Does He judge through the dark cloud?
Thick clouds are a concealment for Him, and He does not see, and He walks on the circle of the heavens.'
Will you keep the old way, upon which iniquitous people trod?
Who were cut off when it was not their time, when a river was poured into their foundation?
Who say to God, 'Turn away from us,' and 'What will the Almighty do to them?'
Yet He filled their houses with good, but the counsel of the wicked was beyond me.
The righteous see and rejoice, and an innocent one mocks them.
Whether their substance was cut off, and their pride consumed by the fire.
Accustom yourself now to be with Him and you will be complete; with them good will come to you.
Now learn Torah from His mouth, and lay His words in your heart.
If you return to the Almighty, you shall be built up; you shall distance injustice from your tents.
Then you shall make a fortification on the earth, and on the rocks of the valleys, [the gold of] Ophir.
And the Almighty shall be [the Judge] of your adversaries, and you shall have abundant silver.
For then you shall delight in the Almighty and lift your countenance to God.
Pray to Him and He will listen to you, and you will pay your vows.
You will make a decision, and it will be accomplished for you, and light will shine on all your ways.
If they are humble, you will say, "Raise up!" and He will save a humble person.
He shall deliver one who is not innocent, and he will be delivered because of the purity of your hands."
Now Job replied and said,
"Even today my speech is bitter; my wound is heavier than my sigh.
Would that I knew and I would find Him; I would come to the place prepared for Him.
I would set out [my] case before Him, and I would fill my mouth with arguments.
I would know the words that He would answer me, and I would understand what He would say to me.
Will He contend with me with much power? He will not place coercion upon me.
There [my] integrity will be proven with Him, and I will extricate [myself] forever from my Judge.
Behold, I go to the east and He is not here, and to the west and I perceive Him not.
In the north, when He made it I do not see; He wraps up the south and I cannot see.
Because He knows the way that is with me; He has tested me that I will emerge like gold.
My foot has held to His path; I have kept His way and do not turn away.
[I kept] the commandment of His lips and I do not remove [it]; more than my daily bread I kept the words of His mouth.
But He is One, and who will answer Him? [Therefore,] whatever His soul desires He does.
For He will complete my sentence, and there are many such things with Him.
Therefore, I am startled by Him; I ponder and am frightened of Him.
Yea, God has made my heart faint, and the Almighty has startled me.
Because I was not cut off from before the darkness, and [because He did not] cover the thick darkness from before me.
Why were the times not hidden from the Almighty? And He Who knows him should not see his days.
[There are some who] remove the landmarks; they violently take away a flock and pasture them.
They lead away the orphan's donkey; they take the widow's ox for a pledge.
They make the needy turn off the road; the poor of the land hide together.
Behold, [as] wild donkeys in the desert, they go out to their work, seeking prey; the wilderness yields bread for his young men.
In the field, they reap his produce, and the wicked gather the plants of the vineyard.
They make them lie all night naked without clothing and without a cover in the cold.
From the stream of the mountains they become wet, and without shelter they embrace the rocks.
They rob from the breast of the orphan, and they take a pledge from a poor man.
They made [him] go naked without clothing and [from] the hungry they carried off the sheaves.
Between their rows they make oil; they tread the winepresses but they are thirsty.
From the city people groan, and the soul of the slain cries out; yet God does not impute it for unseemliness.
They were among those who rebelled because of rain; they did not recognize His ways, neither did they sit in His paths.
Should one rise in daylight, he would murder, he would slay the poor and the needy, and at night he would be like a thief.
And the eye of the adulterer awaits evening, saying, "No eye will see me," and he puts a mask on his face.
In the dark, he digs under houses; by day, they lock themselves in; they know no light.
For together morning is to them [as] the shadow of death, for he recognizes the terrors of the shadow of death.
He is light upon the face of the water; their portion in the earth is cursed; he does not turn by the way of the vineyards.
Dryness and heat they steal away, [also] snow water; [they descended to] the grave [because] they had sinned.
The womb forgets him; he is sweet to the worms; he will no longer be remembered. Injustice was broken like a tree.
He feeds the barren woman who will not bear, but he does not adorn the widow.
And He draws the mighty men with His strength; he rises and does not believe in his life.
He grants him safety and he relies [upon it], but His eyes are on their ways.
They are taken away in a second and he is no more, and they are crushed; like all they are gathered in, and like the tip of an ear of grain they will be cut off.
And if it is not so, then who will prove me a liar and make my words as nought?"
Now Bildad the Shuhite answered and said,
"Dominion and fear are with Him; He makes peace in His heights.
Have His troops a number, and on whom does His light not shine?
How then can man be just with God, and how can one born of woman be clean?
Behold, He removes the moon and it will not shine, and the stars are not pure in His eyes.
How much less, man, who is a worm, and the son of man, who is a maggot!"
Then Job replied and said,
"How have you helped the powerless, saved the one who has no strength in his arm?
How have you advised the one without wisdom, and plentifully declared sound knowledge?
Whom did you tell these words, and whose breath emerged from you?
Gehinnom is hollow beneath the water and its denizens.
Sheol is naked before Him, and there is no cover for Abaddon.
He stretches out the north over chaos; He suspends the earth on nothing.
He binds water in His clouds, and the cloud does not split beneath it.
He closes in the face of His throne; He spreads His cloud over it.
He encircled a boundary on the face of the water, until the ending of light with darkness.
The pillars of the heavens trembled and are astonished from His rebuke.
With His strength, the sea wrinkled, and with His understanding, He smote Rahab.
By His breath He made the heavens a tent; His hand caused pain to the bar- like serpent.
Behold these are the outskirts of His ways, and what implication of any matter can be understood therein, and who understands the thunder of His mighty deeds?"
Then Job again took up his parable and said,
"As God lives, Who has taken away my right, and the Almighty has embittered my soul.
For as long as my soul is within me and the spirit of God is in my nostrils,
my lips will speak no injustice and my tongue will utter no deceit.
Far be it from me that I should justify you; until I die, I will not give up my innocence.
I have maintained my righteousness, and I will not let it go; my heart will not reproach [me] because of my days.
My enemy shall be like a wicked man and he who rises up against me like an unjust one.
For what is the hope of a flatterer who robs, when God casts off his soul?
Will God hearken to his cry when trouble befalls him?
Or will he delight with the Almighty? Will he call God at all times?
I will instruct you [what is] in God's hand; what is with the Almighty I will not conceal.
Behold all of you have seen; now why do you become altogether vain?
This is the portion of a wicked man with God, and the inheritance of the powerful, which they receive from the Almighty.
If his sons increase, they will be for the sword, and his grandchildren will not be sated with bread.
His survivors will be buried in death, and his widows will not weep.
If he gathers money like dust and prepares clothing like clay,
he will prepare, and a righteous man will wear [them], and He will distribute [his] money to the innocent.
He builds his house as a moth, and as a booth that a watchman made.
He dies rich and will not be gathered in; he opened his eyes and he is not here.
Terrors shall overtake him like water; at night a tempest snatches him away.
The east wind carries him off and he goes away, and it sweeps him out of his place.
And he will cast upon him and not have compassion; from his hand he will flee.
They clap their hands over them, and those of his place hiss over him.
For silver has a mine, and gold has a place where it is refined.
Iron is taken from earth and copper is smelted from stone.
He made an end to darkness, and every end He fathoms-a stone of darkness and the shadow of death.
A stream burst forth from the place of its flow; those who cause the foot to be forgotten are removed, yea, from man they are lifted up.
A land from which bread emerged, and its place was as though turned into fire.
Its stones [were] a place of sapphire, and it had gold dust.
A path unknown to brigands and which the eye of a vulture did not see.
Proud beasts did not tread it, neither did a lion pass by it.
He stretched His hand upon the flinty rock; He turned it over from the root of the mountains.
In the rocks, He split rivers, and His eye saw all precious things.
He bound up the depths of the rivers, and [from] Taalumah He brings out light.
But wisdom-whence will it be found, and where is the place of understanding?
No mortal knows its value, and it will not be found in the land of the living.
The deep says, "It is not in me," and the sea says, "It is not with me."
Fine gold cannot be given in its place, neither can silver be weighed out as its price.
It cannot be praised with jewelry of Ophir, with precious onyx and sapphire.
Neither gold nor glass can equal it, nor is a pure golden vessel its exchange.
Coral and crystal cannot be mentioned, and the striving for wisdom [is more precious] than pearls.
The topaz of Kush cannot equal it; it cannot be praised with jewelry of pure gold.
Now whence does wisdom come, and where is the place of understanding?
It is hidden from the eyes of all living, and it is concealed from the winged creatures of the heavens.
Destruction and death said, "With our ears we heard its report."
God understood its way, and He knew its place.
For He looks to the ends of the earth, and He sees under all the heavens.
To make a weight for the wind, and He meted out the water with a measure,
when He made a decree for the rain and a way for the clouds [and] the thunders.
Then He saw and counted it, prepared it, yea, searched it out.
And He said to man, 'Behold, the fear of the Lord is wisdom and shunning evil is understanding.' "
Then Job again took up his parable and said,
"Would that I were as [in] my early months, as [in] the days that God watched over me,
when He lit His candle over my head; by His light I would go through the darkness.
As I was in my early days, when God's counsel was upon my tent.
When the Almighty was still with me, [and] my young men were around me;
When I washed my feet with cream, and the rock that was with me would pour forth rivulets of oil;
When I would go out to the gate upon the ceiling; in the square I would prepare my seat.
Youths saw me and hid, and old men rose and stood.
Princes refrained from talking and laid [their] hand on their mouth.
The voice of nobles was hushed, and their tongues stuck to their palates.
For the ear [that] heard praised me, and the eye [that] saw bore witness for me.
For I would deliver the poor who cried out, and the orphan, and one who had no one to help him.
The blessing of the lost one would come upon me, and I would make the widow's heart sing for joy.
I put on righteousness and it clothed me; like a coat and a turban was my judgment.
I was eyes for the blind, and I was feet for the lame.
I was a father to the needy, and a cause that I did not know, I would investigate.
I broke the fangs of the unjust, and plucked the prey out of his teeth.
And I said, I will perish with my nest, and I will multiply days as the phoenix.
My root will be open to water, and dew will lodge in my branches.
My honor which is with me will be renewed, and my bow will become stronger in my hand.
They listened to me and waited, and kept silence for my counsel.
After my word, they would not ask again, and my speech would drip upon them.
And they waited for me as for rain, and they opened their mouth after a long time.
If I would jest with them, they would not believe it, and they would not cast down the light of my countenance.
I would choose their way and sit at the head, and I would dwell as a king in the troop, as one consoles mourners.
But now, those younger in days than I laugh at me; those whose fathers I despised, to put them with the sheep dogs.
Moreover, why did I need the strength of their hands; old age was wasted on them.
Because of want and because of hunger, they sat in solitude; they would flee to desolation, to the darkness of waste and desolation.
They pluck salt-wort on shrubs, and the roots of juniper bushes were their fare.
They are driven forth from the midst [of the city], they shout at them as [at] a thief.
To dwell in the crevices of the valleys, in holes of earth and rocks.
Among the shrubs they bray; under the nettles they gather.
Sons of churls, sons of ignoble men were broken from the land.
But now I have become their song, and I have become their conversation piece.
They abhor me, they have distanced themselves from me, and from my face they have spared no spittle.
For He untied my bowstring and afflicted me, and they have cast off the bridle before me.
On my right, "little sprouts" stand; they push away my feet and they cast up against me their ways of destruction.
They break up my path; they serve to increase my calamity, although they derive no help therefrom.
As [through] a wide breach they come; under [cover of] darkness they roll upon [me].
Terrors turned upon me; they pursue my nobility as a spirit, and my salvation passed by like a cloud.
And now, my soul pours out upon me; days of affliction seize me.
At night, my bones are picked off me and my sinews have no rest.
By great force is my garment changed; like the opening of my shirt it girds me.
It directed me to the mud, and I was compared to dust and ashes.
I cry out to You but You do not answer me; I stood, and You ponder me.
You became cruel to me; with the strength of Your hand You manifest hatred to me.
You lift me up to the spirit, You cause me to ride [on it], and weakness melts me away.
For I knew that You would return me to death and to the meeting place of all living.
But not with destruction does He stretch forth his hand; if with His misfortune, He would dandle them.
whether I did not weep for one who had a difficult time, or whether my soul was [not] grieved for the needy.
For I hoped for good and evil came, and I looked forward to light and pitch darkness came.
My innards seethed and did not become silent; days of affliction came before me.
I went blackened without the sun; I rose in the congregation and I would cry out.
I was a brother to jackals and a companion to ostriches.
My skin, which was upon me, was blackened, and my bones dried out from the heat.
And my harp became mournful, and my flute [turned] into the voice of weepers.
I made a covenant with my eyes, and why should I gaze upon a virgin?
Now what is the portion of God from above and the heritage of the Almighty from on high?
Is not misfortune for the unjust and deliverance for workers of iniquity?
Will He not see my ways and count all my steps?
Whether I went with falsehood, and my foot hastened upon deceit.
May He weigh me with a just scale and may God know my innocence!
If my foot has turned away from the road and my heart has gone after my eyes and any wrong has clung to my hands,
may I sow and another eat, and produce be uprooted.
If my heart was enticed to a woman, and if I lurked at my neighbor's doorway,
may my wife grind for someone else, and may others kneel over her.
For that is lewdness, and it is iniquity deserving punishment.
For it is fire; it consumes to destruction, and it uproots all my grain.
If I rejected the judgment of my slave or my bondwoman in their cause with me,
then what will I do when God arises and when He visits what will I answer Him?
Did not my Maker make him in the womb, and [did not] One form us both in the womb?
Did I refrain from the desire of the poor, or did I cause the eyes of a widow to fail?
Did I eat my morsel alone and did no orphan eat therefrom?
For, from my youth it raised me like a father, and from my mother's womb I led it.
Did I see a person perishing without a garment or that a needy person had no covering?
Did not his loins bless me, and with the fleece of my lambs [did he not] warm himself?
If I raised my hand against an orphan because I saw my help in the gate,
may my shoulder fall from its shoulder-blade and may my arm be broken from its bone.
For the misfortune from God is fear to me, and I cannot bear its weight.
If I put my hope in gold, and to jewelry I said, 'My confidence,'
If I rejoiced because my wealth was great and because my hand found much;
If I saw light shining and the moon becoming brighter,
And my heart was secretly enticed, and my mouth kissed my hand,
this too is iniquity that bears punishment, for I would have denied God above.
If I rejoiced with the misfortune of my enemy, and was aroused because harm had befallen him,
but I did not allow my palate to sin, to ask his soul through an oath.
If the people of my tent did not say, 'Who will give [us] of his flesh? We will not be sated.'
A stranger did not lodge outside; my doors I would open to the road.
Did I, like men, cover my transgressions, to conceal my iniquity in my hiding place?
For I would subdue a great multitude, and the most contemptible of families frighten me; yet I remain silent and do not go outside the doorway.
Would that I were given one who will listen to me; behold my inscription; may the Almighty bear witness for me and may my opponent write a book.
Would I not carry him on my shoulder, bind it to me as crowns?
I will tell him the number of my steps; I will draw him near, as a prince.
If my soil complains about me, and its furrows weep together,
if I consumed its strength without money, and I caused pain to its owner,
instead of wheat, thistles shall emerge, and instead of barley, noisome weeds. Job's words are ended."
Now these three men ceased to answer Job because he considered himself righteous.
Then Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite of the family of Ram became angry; he became angry with Job because he thought himself [more] righteous than God.
He became angry with his three friends because they found no answer and condemned Job.
Now Elihu waited [to reply] to Job with words because they were older than he in days.
Then Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of the three men, and he became angry.
Then Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite raised his voice and said, "I am young in days and you are very old; therefore, I was awestricken, and I feared to declare my opinion to you.
I said, 'Days speak, and many years impart wisdom.'
Indeed, it is a spirit in man, and the breath of the Almighty permits them to understand.
Neither do great men gain wisdom, nor do elders understand judgment.
Therefore, I said, 'Listen to me; I will express my opinion, yea I too.'
Behold I have awaited your words; I have hearkened for your reasons, until you search out the words.
Yea, I attended to you, and behold, there is no one of you to convince Job, to answer words appropriate for him.
Lest you say, 'We have found wisdom; God will crush him, and not a man.'
He did not set up words against me; I would not reply to him with your sayings.
They were dismayed; they answered no more. Words have removed themselves from them.
And I waited for they did not speak, for they remained silent; they no longer answered.
I, too, will answer my share; I, too, will express my opinion.
For I am full of words; the wind of my stomach distresses me.
Behold my belly is like wine that is not opened, like new wineskins, which will burst.
Let me speak so that I will be relieved; let me open my lips and reply.
I pray you, let me not respect any man's person, neither will I euphemize toward any man.
For I do not know how to euphemize; or else my Maker would carry me away.
But listen to my words, Job, I pray you, and hearken to all my speech.
Behold now I have opened my mouth; my tongue has spoken with my palate.
My words are [with] the uprightness of my heart, and with knowledge my lips speak clear [words].
The spirit of God made me, and the breath of the Almighty keeps me alive.
If you can, answer me; set up before me and stand.
Behold I am like your mouth to God; I was also formed out of clay.
Behold my awe will not terrify you, and my coercion will not weigh heavily upon you.
You spoke but in my hearing, and the voice of [your] words I have heard.
'I am innocent without transgression; I am clean, and I have no iniquity.
Behold He finds pretenses against me; He considers me His enemy.
He puts my feet into the stocks; He watches all my ways.'
Behold this. 'You are not right,' I will answer you, for God exceeds man.
Why do you contend with Him because He does not answer any of his matters?
For God answers in one way and in two, to one who does not see it.
In a dream, a vision of the night, when sound sleep falls upon men, in the slumbers on the bed.
Then He opens the ear of men, and with their chastisement He seals [them].
To restrain man from a deed; and He covers haughtiness from man.
He withholds his soul from the pit, and his life from perishing by the sword.
And he is chastised with pain on his bed, and most of his bones, [since he is] strong.
And his living spirit causes him to abhor food, and his soul choice morsels.
His flesh is consumed from sight, and his bones are dislocated to unsightliness.
And his soul approaches the pit, and his life to the destroyers.
If there is an angel over him, an intercessor, one out of a thousand, to declare for a man his uprightness,
He is gracious to him, and He says, 'Redeem him from descending to the pit. I have found ransom.'
His flesh is more tender than in childhood; he will be restored to the days of his youth.
He entreats God and placates Him, and he sees His countenance in prayer, and He requites man [according to] his righteousness.
He makes a row of men and says, 'I sinned, and I perverted what was straight, but I did not profit.'
He redeemed his soul from perishing in the pit, and his living spirit shall see the light.
Behold God does all these, twice or thrice with man.
To bring back his soul from the pit to be enlightened with the light of life.
Mark well, Job; listen to me. Be still and I will speak.
If you have words, answer me; speak, because I wish to justify you.
If not, you listen to me; be silent and I will teach you wisdom.' "
Now Elihu raised his voice and said,
"You wise men, hearken to my words, and you knowledgeable ones, give ear to me.
For the ear tests words, as the palate tastes food.
Let us choose judgment for ourselves; let us know among ourselves what is good.
For Job said, 'I am righteous, and God has deprived me of my right.
Because of my sentence, I call [Him] a liar. My wound is incurable without transgression.'
Who is a man like Job, who drinks derision like water?
[Who] went on the road to accompany workers of iniquity, and to go with men of wickedness?
For he said, 'A man derives no benefit when he desires [to go] with God.'
Therefore, men of understanding, hearken to me; far be it for God [to commit] wickedness or for the Almighty to [commit] injustice.
For He recompenses man for his deed, and according to man's way He causes him to find.
Surely God does not condemn and the Almighty does not pervert justice.
Who gave Him a charge over the earth, and who disposed the entire world?
If He puts His heart to it, His spirit and His soul He would gather in to Himself.
All flesh would perish together, and man would return to the dust.
And if you wish, understand; hearken to this, lend your ears to the sound of my words.
Will He heal even one who hates judgment? Will you accuse even a very righteous One?
Is it proper to say of a king, 'scoundrel'; 'wicked,' of nobles?
Who did not respect princes, and a prince was not recognized before a poor man, for they are all the work of His hands.
In a moment, they die, and at midnight a nation quakes and passes away; they remove their strength-it is not in their hands.
For His eyes are upon man's ways, and He sees all his steps.
There is neither darkness nor the shadow of death wherein workers of iniquity may hide.
For He will not place additional [guilt] on a man to go to God in judgment.
He shatters the mighty without number and He stands others in their stead.
Because He recognizes their deeds; He turns night [upon them] and they are crushed.
In the place of the wicked He smote them, in the place of viewers
Because they turned away from following Him, and they did not understand any of His ways
To bring upon Him the cry of the poor, and He hears the cry of the afflicted.
When He quiets [them], who will deal wickedly? When He hides His face, who will see Him?-whether [it be done] to a nation or to a man, alike.
That a flattering man shall not reign, because of the snares of the people.
For to God should be said, 'I will bear it; I will not destroy [myself].
Besides what I see, You instruct me; if I have committed injustice, I will not continue.'
From you[r counsel] should He pay it, for you despised [your life]? Should you choose and not I? And what you know, speak?
Men of understanding will say to me, and a wise man will listen to me,
Job does not speak with knowledge, and his words are without sense.
My Father! May Job be tried to eternity, so that there be repentances among men of iniquity.
For he adds transgression to his sin; among us he speaks loquaciously and multiplies his words to God."
Then Elihu raised his voice and said,
"Do you consider this to be customary, what you said,-'My righteousness is greater than [that of] God'?
That you say, 'What will it benefit you? What profit will I have more than if I had sinned?'
I will give you a reply, and your companions with you.
Gaze at the heavens and see, and view the skies, which are higher than you.
If you sinned, what do you do to Him, and if your transgressions are many, what do you do to Him?
If you are righteous, what do you give Him? Or what does He take from your hand?
Your wickedness [affects] a man like yourself, and your righteousness a son of man.
Because of the many oppressed ones, they cause [people] to cry out; they cry for help from the arm of the mighty.
And he did not say, 'Where is God, my Maker, Who deals destruction at night,
Who teaches us [more] than the beasts of the earth, and Who makes us wiser than the birds of the skies?'
There they cry out and He does not answer, because of the pride of the wicked.
Indeed, God will not hear vanity, neither will the Almighty see it.
Surely you who say [that] you do not see Him should present your case before Him and wait for Him.
And now, what He visited [of] His wrath is nothing, and He did not know because of the great multiplicity.
As for Job, he opens his mouth with vanity; he increases words without knowledge."
Then Elihu continued and said,
"Wait awhile for me and I will tell you, for God has more words.
I will take up my knowledge from afar, and to my Maker I will ascribe righteousness.
For indeed, my words are not false; you have perfect knowledge.
Behold God is great and will not despise; He is great in strength of heart.
He does not preserve the life of the wicked, but He gives the poor their right.
He does not withdraw His eyes from the righteous, and with kings on the throne He seats them to eternity and they are exalted.
And if they are bound with chains, are caught with ropes of poverty,
He tells them their deed and their transgressions, for they increase.
He opens their ears to discipline and commands that they repent of iniquity.
If they understand and worship [Him], they will complete their days with goodness and their years with pleasantness.
And if they do not take heed, they will pass away by the sword and perish because of lack of knowledge.
But the wicked of heart bring about wrath; they do not beg mercy when He binds them.
Their soul shall die by strangulation, and their living spirit among the profligate.
He extricates a poor man in his poverty and opens their ear through oppression.
Moreover, it allured you from the narrow mouth, that is wide, not cramped below; and the bedecking of your table shall be full of fatness.
And if you have had your fill of the sentence of the wicked, the judgment and the sentence will support [you].
For [there shall be] wrath, lest it entice you to multiply [words], and great ransom will not turn you away.
Will you set up your prayer so that no trouble [befall you], nor any forces of strength?
Do not yearn for the night when peoples are taken away [as they stand] in their place.
Beware, do not turn to iniquity, for you chose this over poverty.
Behold God deals loftily in His power; who is a teacher like Him?
Who charged Him with His way, and who said, 'You have performed an injustice'?
Mention [this] for you will magnify His work, which men have seen.
All men have seen it; mortal man looks from afar.
Behold God is great and we do not know; the number of His years is unfathomable.
For He increases drops of water; they pour rain into His cloud.
That the heavens drip; yea, they drip because of a great man.
Or will one understand the spreading of a cloud, the darkness of His pavilion?
Behold He spread His rain over it, and He covered the roots of the sea.
For He judges the nations therewith; He gives food to one who has many [children].
Over the clouds He covers the rain, and He commands it through one who prays.
Their beloved one preaches to them; [this is] the acquisition, for it also ascends on high.
From this too does my heart quake and spring from its place.
Hear attentively the noise of His voice and the sound that emanates from His mouth.
Beneath the entire heaven I have seen it, and His light is upon the ends of the earth.
In its wake, a voice roars; it thunders with the voice of its pride, and He will not cut them off for his voice will be heard.
God thunders with His voice wondrous [thunders]; He performs great deeds, but we do not know.
For He says to the snow, 'Be upon the earth'; likewise to the shower of rain and to the showers of His mighty rain.
By the hand of every man he seals so that every man should know his deed.
The beasts go into ambush, and in their dens they dwell.
From the Chamber comes a tempest, and from Mezarim the cold.
From the breath of God He gives forth ice and the breadth of waters in a flood.
Aph Beri burdens the cloud; he scatters His rain cloud.
And he turns around in circuits by His guidance for their work; whatever He commands them upon the face of the habitable world,
Whether for the rod, whether for His land, or for kindness that He cause it to come.
Hearken to this, Job; stand still and ponder the wonders of God.
Do you know how God places upon them and the rain of His cloud appears?
Do you know about the revelations of the clouds, of the wonders of Him Who is perfect in knowledge?
How your garments are warm when the earth is silenced from the south wind?
Did you spread out the skies with Him, which are as strong as a molten mirror?
Let us know what we shall say to Him; we cannot set up [judgment] because of darkness.
Need it be told to Him when I speak, or need a man tell what is kept a secret?
And now, they did not see the rain; it is [like] bright [clouds] in the skies, and a wind came and cleared them away.
Gold[en splendor] comes from the north; on God there is an awesome glory.
We have not found the Almighty great in power, and with judgment and much righteousness He does not afflict.
Therefore, men fear Him; He does not look upon any wise of heart."
Then the Lord answered Job from the tempest and said,
"Who is this who gives dark counsel, with words, without knowledge?
Now gird your loins like a man, and I will ask you and [you] tell Me.
Where were you when I founded the earth? Tell if you know understanding.
Who placed its measures if you know, or who extended a line over it?
On what were its sockets sunk, or who laid its cornerstone?
When the morning stars sing together, and all the angels of God shout?
And [who] shut up the sea with doors when it broke forth and issued out of the womb?
When I made the cloud its raiment and the dark cloud its wrapping?
And broke for it My prescribed limit, and placed a bar and doors?
And said, 'Until here you may come but no further, and here [your strength] shall place your waves with pride.'
In [all] your days, did you command the morning? Did you tell the dawn its place?
To grasp the corners of the earth so that the wicked shall be shaken from it?
The seal changes like clay and they shall stand like a garment.
And their light shall be withheld from the wicked, and the high arm shall be broken.
Have you come until the locks of the sea, and have you walked in the searching out of the deep?
Have the gates of death been revealed to you, and do you see the gates of the shadow of death?
Do you understand [everything] until the breadths of the earth? Tell if you know it all.
Which is the way to [the place] where the light dwells, and as for darkness-where is its place?
That you should take it to its border and that you should understand the paths of its house?
You knew- for then you were born, and the number of your days would be many.
Have you come to the treasures of snow, and did you see the treasures of hail?
That I saved for a time of trouble, for a day of battle and war?
